StdString.h

00001 // =============================================================================
00002 //  FILE:  StdString.h
00003 //  AUTHOR: Joe O'Leary (with outside help noted in comments)
00004 //
00005 //    If you find any bugs in this code, please let me know:
00006 //
00007 //        jmoleary@earthlink.net
00008 //        http://www.joeo.net/stdstring.htm (a bit outdated)
00009 //
00010 //      The latest version of this code should always be available at the
00011 //      following link:
00012 //
00013 //              http://www.joeo.net/code/StdString.zip (Dec 6, 2003)
00014 //
00015 //
00016 //  REMARKS:
00017 //    This header file declares the CStdStr template.  This template derives
00018 //    the Standard C++ Library basic_string<> template and add to it the
00019 //    the following conveniences:
00020 //      - The full MFC CString set of functions (including implicit cast)
00021 //      - writing to/reading from COM IStream interfaces
00022 //      - Functional objects for use in STL algorithms
00023 //
00024 //    From this template, we intstantiate two classes:  CStdStringA and
00025 //    CStdStringW.  The name "CStdString" is just a #define of one of these,
00026 //    based upone the UNICODE macro setting
00027 //
00028 //    This header also declares our own version of the MFC/ATL UNICODE-MBCS
00029 //    conversion macros.  Our version looks exactly like the Microsoft's to
00030 //    facilitate portability.
00031 //
00032 //  NOTE:
00033 //    If you you use this in an MFC or ATL build, you should include either
00034 //    afx.h or atlbase.h first, as appropriate.
00035 //

00267 //          data() in order to ensure the changed string buffer is not
00268 //          reference-counted (in those implementations that refcount).

00273 //          in and implement it.

00275 //          EXACTLY as CString's do.  So now you can send a CString out

00299 //          caused infinite recursion and stack overflow
00300 //          - Added member functions to simplify the process of
00301 //          persisting CStdStrings to/from DCOM IStream interfaces 
00302 //          - Added functional objects (e.g. StdStringLessNoCase) that
00303 //          allow CStdStrings to be used as keys STL map objects with
00304 //          case-insensitive comparison 
00305 //          - Added array indexing operators (i.e. operator[]).  I
00306 //          originally assumed that these were unnecessary and would be
00307 //          inherited from basic_string.  However, without them, Visual
00308 //          C++ complains about ambiguous overloads when you try to use
00309 //          them.  Thanks to Julian Selman to pointing this out.

00325 // Avoid multiple inclusion
00326 
00327 #ifndef STDSTRING_H
00328 #define STDSTRING_H
00329 
00330 // When using VC, turn off browser references
00331 // Turn off unavoidable compiler warnings
00332 
00333 #if defined(_MSC_VER) && (_MSC_VER > 1100)
00334   #pragma component(browser, off, references, "CStdString")
00335   #pragma warning (disable : 4290) // C++ Exception Specification ignored
00336   #pragma warning (disable : 4127) // Conditional expression is constant
00337   #pragma warning (disable : 4097) // typedef name used as synonym for class name
00338 #endif
00339 
00340 // Borland warnings to turn off
00341 
00342 #ifdef __BORLANDC__
00343     #pragma option push -w-inl
00344 //  #pragma warn -inl   // Turn off inline function warnings
00345 #endif
00346 
00347 // SS_IS_INTRESOURCE
00348 // -----------------
00349 //    A copy of IS_INTRESOURCE from VC7.  Because old VC6 version of winuser.h
00350 //    doesn't have this.
00351 
00352 #define SS_IS_INTRESOURCE(_r) (false)
00353 
00354 #if !defined (SS_ANSI) && defined(_MSC_VER)
00355   #undef SS_IS_INTRESOURCE
00356   #if defined(_WIN64)
00357     #define SS_IS_INTRESOURCE(_r) (((unsigned __int64)(_r) >> 16) == 0)
00358   #else
00359     #define SS_IS_INTRESOURCE(_r) (((unsigned long)(_r) >> 16) == 0)
00360   #endif
00361 #endif
00362 
00363 
00364 // MACRO: SS_UNSIGNED
00365 // ------------------
00366 //      This macro causes the addition of a constructor and assignment operator
00367 //      which take unsigned characters.  CString has such functions and in order
00368 //      to provide maximum CString-compatability, this code needs them as well.
00369 //      In practice you will likely never need these functions...
00370 
00371 //#define SS_UNSIGNED
00372 
00373 #ifdef SS_ALLOW_UNSIGNED_CHARS
00374   #define SS_UNSIGNED
00375 #endif
00376 
00377 // MACRO: SS_SAFE_FORMAT
00378 // ---------------------
00379 //      This macro provides limited compatability with a questionable CString
00380 //      "feature".  You can define it in order to avoid a common problem that
00381 //      people encounter when switching from CString to CStdString.
00382 //
00383 //      To illustrate the problem -- With CString, you can do this:
00384 //
00385 //          CString sName("Joe");
00386 //          CString sTmp;
00387 //          sTmp.Format("My name is %s", sName);                    // WORKS!
00388 //
00389 //      However if you were to try this with CStdString, your program would
00390 //      crash.
00391 //
00392 //          CStdString sName("Joe");
00393 //          CStdString sTmp;
00394 //          sTmp.Format("My name is %s", sName);                    // CRASHES!
00395 //
00396 //      You must explicitly call c_str() or cast the object to the proper type
00397 //
00398 //          sTmp.Format("My name is %s", sName.c_str());            // WORKS!
00399 //          sTmp.Format("My name is %s", static_cast<PCSTR>(sName));// WORKS!
00400 //          sTmp.Format("My name is %s", (PCSTR)sName);       // WORKS!
00401 //
00402 //      This is because it is illegal to pass anything but a POD type as a
00403 //      variadic argument to a variadic function (i.e. as one of the "..."
00404 //      arguments).  The type const char* is a POD type.  The type CStdString
00405 //      is not.  Of course, neither is the type CString, but CString lets you do
00406 //      it anyway due to the way they laid out the class in binary.  I have no
00407 //      control over this in CStdString since I derive from whatever
00408 //      implementation of basic_string is available.
00409 //
00410 //      However if you have legacy code (which does this) that you want to take
00411 //      out of the MFC world and you don't want to rewrite all your calls to
00412 //      Format(), then you can define this flag and it will no longer crash.
00413 //
00414 //      Note however that this ONLY works for Format(), not sprintf, fprintf, 
00415 //      etc.  If you pass a CStdString object to one of those functions, your
00416 //      program will crash.  Not much I can do to get around this, short of
00417 //      writing substitutes for those functions as well.
00418 
00419 #define SS_SAFE_FORMAT  // use new template style Format() function
00420 
00421 
00422 // MACRO: SS_NO_IMPLICIT_CAST
00423 // --------------------------
00424 //      Some people don't like the implicit cast to const char* (or rather to
00425 //      const CT*) that CStdString (and MFC's CString) provide.  That was the
00426 //      whole reason I created this class in the first place, but hey, whatever
00427 //      bakes your cake.  Just #define this macro to get rid of the the implicit
00428 //      cast.
00429 
00430 //#define SS_NO_IMPLICIT_CAST // gets rid of operator const CT*()
00431 
00432 
00433 // MACRO: SS_NO_REFCOUNT
00434 // ---------------------
00435 //    turns off reference counting at the assignment level.  Only needed
00436 //    for the version of basic_string<> that comes with Visual C++ versions
00437 //    6.0 or earlier, and only then in some heavily multithreaded scenarios.
00438 //    Uncomment it if you feel you need it.
00439 
00440 //#define SS_NO_REFCOUNT
00441 
00442 // MACRO: SS_WIN32
00443 // ---------------
00444 //      When this flag is set, we are building code for the Win32 platform and
00445 //      may use Win32 specific functions (such as LoadString).  This gives us
00446 //      a couple of nice extras for the code.
00447 //
00448 //      Obviously, Microsoft's is not the only compiler available for Win32 out
00449 //      there.  So I can't just check to see if _MSC_VER is defined to detect
00450 //      if I'm building on Win32.  So for now, if you use MS Visual C++ or
00451 //      Borland's compiler, I turn this on.  Otherwise you may turn it on
00452 //      yourself, if you prefer
00453 
00454 #if defined(_MSC_VER) || defined(__BORLANDC__) || defined(_WIN32)
00455     #define SS_WIN32
00456 #endif
00457 
00458 // MACRO: SS_ANSI
00459 // --------------
00460 //      When this macro is defined, the code attempts only to use ANSI/ISO
00461 //      standard library functions to do it's work.  It will NOT attempt to use
00462 //      any Win32 of Visual C++ specific functions -- even if they are
00463 //      available.  You may define this flag yourself to prevent any Win32
00464 //      of VC++ specific functions from being called. 
00465 
00466 // If we're not on Win32, we MUST use an ANSI build
00467 
00468 #ifndef SS_WIN32
00469     #if !defined(SS_NO_ANSI)
00470         #define SS_ANSI
00471     #endif
00472 #endif
00473 
00474 // MACRO: SS_ALLOCA
00475 // ----------------
00476 //      Some implementations of the Standard C Library have a non-standard
00477 //      function known as alloca().  This functions allows one to allocate a
00478 //      variable amount of memory on the stack.  It is needed to implement
00479 //      the ASCII/MBCS conversion macros.
00480 //
00481 //      I wanted to find some way to determine automatically if alloca() is
00482 //    available on this platform via compiler flags but that is asking for
00483 //    trouble.  The crude test presented here will likely need fixing on
00484 //    other platforms.  Therefore I'll leave it up to you to fiddle with
00485 //    this test to determine if it exists.  Just make sure SS_ALLOCA is or
00486 //    is not defined as appropriate and you control this feature.
00487 
00488 #if defined(_MSC_VER) && !defined(SS_ANSI)
00489   #define SS_ALLOCA
00490 #endif
00491 
00492 
00493 // MACRO: SS_MBCS
00494 // --------------
00495 //    Setting this macro means you are using MBCS characters.  In MSVC builds,
00496 //    this macro gets set automatically by detection of the preprocessor flag
00497 //    _MBCS.  For other platforms you may set it manually if you wish.  The
00498 //    only effect it currently has is to cause the allocation of more space
00499 //    for wchar_t --> char conversions.
00500 //    Note that MBCS does not mean UNICODE.
00501 //
00502 //  #define SS_MBCS
00503 //
00504 
00505 #ifdef _MBCS
00506   #define SS_MBCS
00507 #endif
00508 
00509 
00510 // MACRO SS_NO_LOCALE
00511 // ------------------
00512 // If your implementation of the Standard C++ Library lacks the <locale> header,
00513 // you can #define this macro to make your code build properly.  Note that this
00514 // is some of my newest code and frankly I'm not very sure of it, though it does
00515 // pass my unit tests.
00516 
00517 // #define SS_NO_LOCALE
00518 
00519 
00520 // Compiler Error regarding _UNICODE and UNICODE
00521 // -----------------------------------------------
00522 // Microsoft header files are screwy.  Sometimes they depend on a preprocessor 
00523 // flag named "_UNICODE".  Other times they check "UNICODE" (note the lack of
00524 // leading underscore in the second version".  In several places, they silently
00525 // "synchronize" these two flags this by defining one of the other was defined. 
00526 // In older version of this header, I used to try to do the same thing. 
00527 //
00528 // However experience has taught me that this is a bad idea.  You get weird
00529 // compiler errors that seem to indicate things like LPWSTR and LPTSTR not being
00530 // equivalent in UNICODE builds, stuff like that (when they MUST be in a proper
00531 // UNICODE  build).  You end up scratching your head and saying, "But that HAS
00532 // to compile!".
00533 //
00534 // So what should you do if you get this error?
00535 //
00536 // Make sure that both macros (_UNICODE and UNICODE) are defined before this
00537 // file is included.  You can do that by either
00538 //
00539 //    a) defining both yourself before any files get included
00540 //    b) including the proper MS headers in the proper order
00541 //    c) including this file before any other file, uncommenting
00542 //       the #defines below, and commenting out the #errors
00543 //
00544 //  Personally I recommend solution a) but it's your call.
00545 
00546 #ifdef _MSC_VER
00547   #if defined (_UNICODE) && !defined (UNICODE)
00548     #error UNICODE defined  but not UNICODE
00549   //  #define UNICODE  // no longer silently fix this
00550   #endif
00551   #if defined (UNICODE) && !defined (_UNICODE)
00552     #error Warning, UNICODE defined  but not _UNICODE
00553   //  #define _UNICODE  // no longer silently fix this
00554   #endif
00555 #endif

00558 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
00559 // MIN and MAX.  The Standard C++ template versions go by so many names (at
00560 // at least in the MS implementation) that you never know what's available 
00561 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
00562 template<class Type>
00563 inline const Type& SSMIN(const Type& arg1, const Type& arg2)
00564 {
00565   return arg2 < arg1 ? arg2 : arg1;
00566 }
00567 template<class Type>
00568 inline const Type& SSMAX(const Type& arg1, const Type& arg2)
00569 {
00570   return arg2 > arg1 ? arg2 : arg1;
00571 }

00573 // If they have not #included W32Base.h (part of my W32 utility library) then
00574 // we need to define some stuff.  Otherwise, this is all defined there.
00575 
00576 #if !defined(W32BASE_H)
00577 
00578   // If they want us to use only standard C++ stuff (no Win32 stuff)
00579 
00580   #ifdef SS_ANSI
00581 
00582     // On Win32 we have TCHAR.H so just include it.  This is NOT violating
00583         // the spirit of SS_ANSI as we are not calling any Win32 functions here.
00584         
00585     #ifdef SS_WIN32
00586 
00587       #include <TCHAR.H>
00588       #include <WTYPES.H>
00589       #ifndef STRICT
00590         #define STRICT
00591       #endif
00592 
00593         // ... but on non-Win32 platforms, we must #define the types we need.
00594 
00595     #else
00596 
00597       typedef const char*   PCSTR;
00598       typedef char*     PSTR;
00599       typedef const wchar_t*  PCWSTR;
00600       typedef wchar_t*    PWSTR;
00601       #ifdef UNICODE
00602         typedef wchar_t   TCHAR;
00603       #else
00604         typedef char    TCHAR;
00605       #endif
00606       typedef wchar_t     OLECHAR;
00607 
00608     #endif  // #ifndef _WIN32

00614       #include <assert.h>
00615       #define ASSERT(f) assert((f))
00616     #endif
00617     #ifndef VERIFY
00618       #ifdef _DEBUG
00619         #define VERIFY(x) ASSERT((x))
00620       #else
00621         #define VERIFY(x) x
00622       #endif
00623     #endif
00624 
00625   #else // ...else SS_ANSI is NOT defined
00626 
00627     #include <TCHAR.H>
00628     #include <WTYPES.H>
00629     #ifndef STRICT
00630       #define STRICT
00631     #endif

00638     #endif

00641         #define VERIFY(x) ASSERT((x))
00642       #else

00644       #endif

00682 // Microsoft defines PCSTR, PCWSTR, etc, but no PCTSTR.  I hate to use the
00683 // versions with the "L" in front of them because that's a leftover from Win 16
00684 // days, even though it evaluates to the same thing.  Therefore, Define a PCSTR
00685 // as an LPCTSTR.
00686 
00687 #if !defined(PCTSTR) && !defined(PCTSTR_DEFINED)
00688   typedef const TCHAR*      PCTSTR;
00689   #define PCTSTR_DEFINED
00690 #endif

00693   typedef const OLECHAR*      PCOLESTR;
00694   #define PCOLESTR_DEFINED
00695 #endif

00699   #define POLESTR_DEFINED
00700 #endif

00716 
00717 // SS_USE_FACET macro and why we need it:
00718 //
00719 // Since I'm a good little Standard C++ programmer, I use locales.  Thus, I
00720 // need to make use of the use_facet<> template function here.   Unfortunately,
00721 // this need is complicated by the fact the MS' implementation of the Standard
00722 // C++ Library has a non-standard version of use_facet that takes more
00723 // arguments than the standard dictates.  Since I'm trying to write CStdString
00724 // to work with any version of the Standard library, this presents a problem.
00725 //
00726 // The upshot of this is that I can't do 'use_facet' directly.  The MS' docs
00727 // tell me that I have to use a macro, _USE() instead.  Since _USE obviously
00728 // won't be available in other implementations, this means that I have to write
00729 // my OWN macro -- SS_USE_FACET -- that evaluates either to _USE or to the
00730 // standard, use_facet.
00731 //
00732 // If you are having trouble with the SS_USE_FACET macro, in your implementation
00733 // of the Standard C++ Library, you can define your own version of SS_USE_FACET.
00734 
00735 #ifndef schMSG
00736   #define schSTR(x)    #x
00737   #define schSTR2(x)  schSTR(x)
00738   #define schMSG(desc) message(__FILE__ "(" schSTR2(__LINE__) "):" #desc)
00739 #endif
00740 
00741 #ifndef SS_USE_FACET
00742 
00743   // STLPort #defines a macro (__STL_NO_EXPLICIT_FUNCTION_TMPL_ARGS) for
00744   // all MSVC builds, erroneously in my opinion.  It causes problems for
00745   // my SS_ANSI builds.  In my code, I always comment out that line.  You'll
00746   // find it in   \stlport\config\stl_msvc.h
00747 
00748   #if defined(__SGI_STL_PORT) && (__SGI_STL_PORT >= 0x400 )
00749 
00750     #if defined(__STL_NO_EXPLICIT_FUNCTION_TMPL_ARGS) && defined(_MSC_VER)
00751       #ifdef SS_ANSI
00752         #pragma schMSG(__STL_NO_EXPLICIT_FUNCTION_TMPL_ARGS defined!!)
00753       #endif
00754     #endif
00755     #define SS_USE_FACET(loc, fac) std::use_facet<fac >(loc)
00756 
00757   #elif defined(_MSC_VER )
00758 
00759     #define SS_USE_FACET(loc, fac) std::_USE(loc, fac)
00760 
00761   // ...and
00762   #elif defined(_RWSTD_NO_TEMPLATE_ON_RETURN_TYPE)
00763 
00764         #define SS_USE_FACET(loc, fac) std::use_facet(loc, (fac*)0)
00765 
00766   #else
00767 
00768     #define SS_USE_FACET(loc, fac) std::use_facet<fac >(loc)
00769 
00770   #endif
00771 
00772 #endif
00773 
00774 // =============================================================================
00775 // UNICODE/MBCS conversion macros.  Made to work just like the MFC/ATL ones.
00776 // =============================================================================
00777 
00778 #include <wchar.h>      // Added to Std Library with Amendment #1.
00779 
00780 // First define the conversion helper functions.  We define these regardless of
00781 // any preprocessor macro settings since their names won't collide. 
00782 
00783 // Not sure if we need all these headers.   I believe ANSI says we do.
00784 
00785 #include <stdio.h>
00786 #include <stdarg.h>
00787 #include <wctype.h>
00788 #include <ctype.h>
00789 #include <stdlib.h>
00790 #ifndef va_start
00791   #include <varargs.h>
00792 #endif

00795 #ifdef SS_NO_LOCALE
00796 
00797   #if defined(_WIN32) || defined (_WIN32_WCE)
00798 
00799     inline PWSTR StdCodeCvt(PWSTR pDstW, int nDst, PCSTR pSrcA, int nSrc, 
00800       UINT acp=CP_ACP)
00801     {
00802       ASSERT(0 != pSrcA);
00803       ASSERT(0 != pDstW);
00804       pDstW[0] = '\0';
00805       MultiByteToWideChar(acp, 0, pSrcA, nSrc, pDstW, nDst);
00806       return pDstW;
00807     }
00808     inline PWSTR StdCodeCvt(PWSTR pDstW, int nDst, PCUSTR pSrcA, int nSrc, 
00809       UINT acp=CP_ACP)
00810     {
00811       return StdCodeCvt(pDstW, nDst, (PCSTR)pSrcA, nSrc, acp);
00812     }
00813 
00814     inline PSTR StdCodeCvt(PSTR pDstA, int nDst, PCWSTR pSrcW, int nSrc, 
00815       UINT acp=CP_ACP)
00816     {
00817       ASSERT(0 != pDstA);
00818       ASSERT(0 != pSrcW);
00819       pDstA[0] = '\0';
00820       WideCharToMultiByte(acp, 0, pSrcW, nSrc, pDstA, nDst, 0, 0);
00821       return pDstA;
00822     }
00823     inline PUSTR StdCodeCvt(PUSTR pDstA, int nDst, PCWSTR pSrcW, int nSrc, 
00824       UINT acp=CP_ACP)
00825     {
00826       return (PUSTR)StdCodeCvt((PSTR)pDstA, nDst, pSrcW, nSrc, acp);
00827     }
00828   #else
00829   #endif
00830 
00831 #else
00832 
00833   // StdCodeCvt - made to look like Win32 functions WideCharToMultiByte
00834   //        and MultiByteToWideChar but uses locales in SS_ANSI
00835   //        builds.  There are a number of overloads.
00836   //              First argument is the destination buffer.
00837   //              Second argument is the source buffer
00838   //#if defined (SS_ANSI) || !defined (SS_WIN32)
00839 
00840   // 'SSCodeCvt' - shorthand name for the codecvt facet we use
00841 
00842   typedef std::codecvt<wchar_t, char, mbstate_t> SSCodeCvt;
00843 
00844   inline PWSTR StdCodeCvt(PWSTR pDstW, int nDst, PCSTR pSrcA, int nSrc,
00845     const std::locale& loc=std::locale())
00846   {
00847     ASSERT(0 != pSrcA);
00848     ASSERT(0 != pDstW);
00849 
00850     pDstW[0]          = '\0'; 
00851 
00852     if ( nSrc > 0 )
00853     {
00854       PCSTR pNextSrcA     = pSrcA;
00855       PWSTR pNextDstW     = pDstW;
00856       SSCodeCvt::result res = SSCodeCvt::ok;
00857       const SSCodeCvt& conv = SS_USE_FACET(loc, SSCodeCvt);
00858       SSCodeCvt::state_type st= { 0 };
00859       res           = conv.in(st,
00860                     pSrcA, pSrcA + nSrc, pNextSrcA,
00861                     pDstW, pDstW + nDst, pNextDstW);
00862 
00863       ASSERT(SSCodeCvt::ok == res);
00864       ASSERT(SSCodeCvt::error != res);
00865       ASSERT(pNextDstW >= pDstW);
00866       ASSERT(pNextSrcA >= pSrcA);
00867 
00868       // Null terminate the converted string
00869 
00870       if ( pNextDstW - pDstW > nDst )
00871         *(pDstW + nDst) = '\0';
00872       else
00873         *pNextDstW = '\0';
00874     }
00875     return pDstW;
00876   }
00877   inline PWSTR StdCodeCvt(PWSTR pDstW, int nDst, PCUSTR pSrcA, int nSrc,
00878     const std::locale& loc=std::locale())
00879   {
00880     return StdCodeCvt(pDstW, nDst, (PCSTR)pSrcA, nSrc, loc);
00881   }
00882 
00883   inline PSTR StdCodeCvt(PSTR pDstA, int nDst, PCWSTR pSrcW, int nSrc,
00884     const std::locale& loc=std::locale())
00885   {
00886     ASSERT(0 != pDstA);
00887     ASSERT(0 != pSrcW);
00888 
00889     pDstA[0]          = '\0'; 
00890 
00891     if ( nSrc > 0 )
00892     {
00893       PSTR pNextDstA      = pDstA;
00894       PCWSTR pNextSrcW    = pSrcW;
00895       SSCodeCvt::result res = SSCodeCvt::ok;
00896       const SSCodeCvt& conv = SS_USE_FACET(loc, SSCodeCvt);
00897       SSCodeCvt::state_type st= { 0 };
00898       res           = conv.out(st,
00899                     pSrcW, pSrcW + nSrc, pNextSrcW,
00900                     pDstA, pDstA + nDst, pNextDstA);
00901 
00902       ASSERT(SSCodeCvt::error != res);
00903       ASSERT(SSCodeCvt::ok == res); // strict, comment out for sanity
00904       ASSERT(pNextDstA >= pDstA);
00905       ASSERT(pNextSrcW >= pSrcW);
00906 
00907       // Null terminate the converted string
00908 
00909       if ( pNextDstA - pDstA > nDst )
00910         *(pDstA + nDst) = '\0';
00911       else
00912         *pNextDstA = '\0';
00913     }
00914     return pDstA;
00915   }
00916 
00917   inline PUSTR StdCodeCvt(PUSTR pDstA, int nDst, PCWSTR pSrcW, int nSrc,
00918     const std::locale& loc=std::locale())
00919   {
00920     return (PUSTR)StdCodeCvt((PSTR)pDstA, nDst, pSrcW, nSrc, loc);
00921   }
00922 
00923 #endif
00924 
00925 
00926 
00927 // Unicode/MBCS conversion macros are only available on implementations of
00928 // the "C" library that have the non-standard _alloca function.  As far as I
00929 // know that's only Microsoft's though I've heard that the function exists
00930 // elsewhere.  
00931     
00932 #if defined(SS_ALLOCA) && !defined SS_NO_CONVERSION
00933 
00934     #include <malloc.h> // needed for _alloca
00935 
00936     // Define our conversion macros to look exactly like Microsoft's to
00937     // facilitate using this stuff both with and without MFC/ATL
00938 
00939     #ifdef _CONVERSION_USES_THREAD_LOCALE
00940 
00941       #ifndef _DEBUG
00942         #define SSCVT int _cvt; _cvt; UINT _acp=GetACP(); \
00943           _acp; PCWSTR _pw; _pw; PCSTR _pa; _pa
00944       #else
00945         #define SSCVT int _cvt = 0; _cvt; UINT _acp=GetACP();\
00946            _acp; PCWSTR _pw=0; _pw; PCSTR _pa=0; _pa
00947       #endif
00948       #define SSA2W(pa) (\
00949         ((_pa = pa) == 0) ? 0 : (\
00950           _cvt = (sslen(_pa)),\
00951           StdCodeCvt((PWSTR) _alloca((_cvt+1)*2), (_cvt+1)*2, \
00952               _pa, _cvt, _acp)))
00953       #define SSW2A(pw) (\
00954         ((_pw = pw) == 0) ? 0 : (\
00955           _cvt = sslen(_pw), \
00956           StdCodeCvt((LPSTR) _alloca((_cvt+1)*2), (_cvt+1)*2, \
00957           _pw, _cvt, _acp)))
00958   #else
00959 
00960       #ifndef _DEBUG
00961         #define SSCVT int _cvt; _cvt; UINT _acp=CP_ACP; _acp;\
00962            PCWSTR _pw; _pw; PCSTR _pa; _pa
00963       #else
00964         #define SSCVT int _cvt = 0; _cvt; UINT _acp=CP_ACP; \
00965           _acp; PCWSTR _pw=0; _pw; PCSTR _pa=0; _pa
00966       #endif
00967       #define SSA2W(pa) (\
00968         ((_pa = pa) == 0) ? 0 : (\
00969           _cvt = (sslen(_pa)),\
00970           StdCodeCvt((PWSTR) _alloca((_cvt+1)*2), (_cvt+1)*2, \
00971           _pa, _cvt)))
00972       #define SSW2A(pw) (\
00973         ((_pw = pw) == 0) ? 0 : (\
00974           _cvt = (sslen(_pw)),\
00975           StdCodeCvt((LPSTR) _alloca((_cvt+1)*2), (_cvt+1)*2, \
00976           _pw, _cvt)))
00977     #endif
00978 
00979     #define SSA2CW(pa) ((PCWSTR)SSA2W((pa)))
00980     #define SSW2CA(pw) ((PCSTR)SSW2A((pw)))
00981 
00982     #ifdef UNICODE
00983       #define SST2A SSW2A
00984       #define SSA2T SSA2W
00985       #define SST2CA  SSW2CA
00986       #define SSA2CT  SSA2CW
00987     // (Did you get a compiler error here about not being able to convert
00988     // PTSTR into PWSTR?  Then your _UNICODE and UNICODE flags are messed 
00989     // up.  Best bet: #define BOTH macros before including any MS headers.)
00990       inline PWSTR  SST2W(PTSTR p)      { return p; }
00991       inline PTSTR  SSW2T(PWSTR p)      { return p; }
00992       inline PCWSTR SST2CW(PCTSTR p)    { return p; }
00993       inline PCTSTR SSW2CT(PCWSTR p)    { return p; }
00994     #else
00995       #define SST2W SSA2W
00996       #define SSW2T SSW2A
00997       #define SST2CW  SSA2CW
00998       #define SSW2CT  SSW2CA
00999       inline PSTR   SST2A(PTSTR p)      { return p; }
01000       inline PTSTR  SSA2T(PSTR p)     { return p; }
01001       inline PCSTR  SST2CA(PCTSTR p)    { return p; }
01002       inline PCTSTR SSA2CT(PCSTR p)     { return p; }
01003     #endif // #ifdef UNICODE
01004 
01005     #if defined(UNICODE)
01006     // in these cases the default (TCHAR) is the same as OLECHAR
01007       inline PCOLESTR SST2COLE(PCTSTR p)    { return p; }
01008       inline PCTSTR SSOLE2CT(PCOLESTR p)  { return p; }
01009       inline POLESTR  SST2OLE(PTSTR p)    { return p; }
01010       inline PTSTR  SSOLE2T(POLESTR p)    { return p; }
01011     #elif defined(OLE2ANSI)
01012     // in these cases the default (TCHAR) is the same as OLECHAR
01013       inline PCOLESTR SST2COLE(PCTSTR p)    { return p; }
01014       inline PCTSTR SSOLE2CT(PCOLESTR p)  { return p; }
01015       inline POLESTR  SST2OLE(PTSTR p)    { return p; }
01016       inline PTSTR  SSOLE2T(POLESTR p)    { return p; }
01017     #else
01018       //CharNextW doesn't work on Win95 so we use this
01019       #define SST2COLE(pa)  SSA2CW((pa))
01020       #define SST2OLE(pa)   SSA2W((pa))
01021       #define SSOLE2CT(po)  SSW2CA((po))
01022       #define SSOLE2T(po)   SSW2A((po))
01023     #endif
01024 
01025     #ifdef OLE2ANSI
01026       #define SSW2OLE   SSW2A
01027       #define SSOLE2W   SSA2W
01028       #define SSW2COLE  SSW2CA
01029       #define SSOLE2CW  SSA2CW
01030       inline POLESTR    SSA2OLE(PSTR p)   { return p; }
01031       inline PSTR     SSOLE2A(POLESTR p)  { return p; }
01032       inline PCOLESTR   SSA2COLE(PCSTR p) { return p; }
01033       inline PCSTR    SSOLE2CA(PCOLESTR p){ return p; }
01034     #else
01035       #define SSA2OLE   SSA2W
01036       #define SSOLE2A   SSW2A
01037       #define SSA2COLE  SSA2CW
01038       #define SSOLE2CA  SSW2CA
01039       inline POLESTR    SSW2OLE(PWSTR p)  { return p; }
01040       inline PWSTR    SSOLE2W(POLESTR p)  { return p; }
01041       inline PCOLESTR   SSW2COLE(PCWSTR p)  { return p; }
01042       inline PCWSTR   SSOLE2CW(PCOLESTR p){ return p; }
01043     #endif
01044

01046     // an 'SS' prefix.  Now we need the real macros.  We'll either
01047     // get them from the macros above or from MFC/ATL. 
01048 
01049   #if defined (USES_CONVERSION)
01050 
01051     #define _NO_STDCONVERSION // just to be consistent
01052 
01053   #else
01054 
01055     #ifdef _MFC_VER
01056 
01057       #include <afxconv.h>
01058       #define _NO_STDCONVERSION // just to be consistent
01059 
01060     #else
01061 
01062       #define USES_CONVERSION SSCVT
01063       #define A2CW      SSA2CW
01064       #define W2CA      SSW2CA
01065       #define T2A       SST2A
01066       #define A2T       SSA2T
01067       #define T2W       SST2W
01068       #define W2T       SSW2T
01069       #define T2CA      SST2CA
01070       #define A2CT      SSA2CT
01071       #define T2CW      SST2CW
01072       #define W2CT      SSW2CT
01073       #define ocslen      sslen
01074       #define ocscpy      sscpy
01075       #define T2COLE      SST2COLE
01076       #define OLE2CT      SSOLE2CT
01077       #define T2OLE     SST2COLE
01078       #define OLE2T     SSOLE2CT
01079       #define A2OLE     SSA2OLE
01080       #define OLE2A     SSOLE2A
01081       #define W2OLE     SSW2OLE
01082       #define OLE2W     SSOLE2W
01083       #define A2COLE      SSA2COLE
01084       #define OLE2CA      SSOLE2CA
01085       #define W2COLE      SSW2COLE
01086       #define OLE2CW      SSOLE2CW

01092 // Define ostring - generic name for std::basic_string<OLECHAR>

01098 
01099 // StdCodeCvt when there's no conversion to be done
01100 inline PSTR StdCodeCvt(PSTR pDst, int nDst, PCSTR pSrc, int nSrc)
01101 {
01102   int nChars = SSMIN(nSrc, nDst);
01103 
01104   if ( nChars > 0 )
01105   {
01106     pDst[0]       = '\0';
01107     std::basic_string<char>::traits_type::copy(pDst, pSrc, nChars);
01108 //    std::char_traits<char>::copy(pDst, pSrc, nChars);
01109     pDst[nChars]  = '\0';
01110   }
01111 
01112   return pDst;
01113 }
01114 inline PSTR StdCodeCvt(PSTR pDst, int nDst, PCUSTR pSrc, int nSrc)
01115 {
01116   return StdCodeCvt(pDst, nDst, (PCSTR)pSrc, nSrc);
01117 }
01118 inline PUSTR StdCodeCvt(PUSTR pDst, int nDst, PCSTR pSrc, int nSrc)
01119 {
01120   return (PUSTR)StdCodeCvt((PSTR)pDst, nDst, pSrc, nSrc);
01121 }
01122 
01123 inline PWSTR StdCodeCvt(PWSTR pDst, int nDst, PCWSTR pSrc, int nSrc)
01124 {
01125   int nChars = SSMIN(nSrc, nDst);
01126 
01127   if ( nChars > 0 )
01128   {
01129     pDst[0]       = '\0';
01130     std::basic_string<wchar_t>::traits_type::copy(pDst, pSrc, nChars);
01131 //    std::char_traits<wchar_t>::copy(pDst, pSrc, nChars);
01132     pDst[nChars]  = '\0';
01133   }
01134 
01135   return pDst;
01136 }
01137 
01138 
01139 // Define tstring -- generic name for std::basic_string<TCHAR>
01140 
01141 #if !defined(tstring) && !defined(TSTRING_DEFINED)
01142   typedef std::basic_string<TCHAR> tstring;
01143   #define TSTRING_DEFINED
01144 #endif
01145 
01146 // a very shorthand way of applying the fix for KB problem Q172398
01147 // (basic_string assignment bug)
01148 
01149 #if defined ( _MSC_VER ) && ( _MSC_VER < 1200 )
01150   #define Q172398(x) (x).erase()
01151 #else
01152   #define Q172398(x)
01153 #endif
01154 
01155 // =============================================================================
01156 // INLINE FUNCTIONS ON WHICH CSTDSTRING RELIES
01157 //
01158 // Usually for generic text mapping, we rely on preprocessor macro definitions
01159 // to map to string functions.  However the CStdStr<> template cannot use
01160 // macro-based generic text mappings because its character types do not get
01161 // resolved until template processing which comes AFTER macro processing.  In
01162 // other words, the preprocessor macro UNICODE is of little help to us in the
01163 // CStdStr template
01164 //
01165 // Therefore, to keep the CStdStr declaration simple, we have these inline
01166 // functions.  The template calls them often.  Since they are inline (and NOT
01167 // exported when this is built as a DLL), they will probably be resolved away
01168 // to nothing. 
01169 //
01170 // Without these functions, the CStdStr<> template would probably have to broken
01171 // out into two, almost identical classes.  Either that or it would be a huge,
01172 // convoluted mess, with tons of "if" statements all over the place checking the
01173 // size of template parameter CT.
01174 // =============================================================================
01175 
01176 #ifdef SS_NO_LOCALE
01177 
01178   // --------------------------------------------------------------------------
01179   // Win32 GetStringTypeEx wrappers
01180   // --------------------------------------------------------------------------
01181   inline bool wsGetStringType(LCID lc, DWORD dwT, PCSTR pS, int nSize, 
01182     WORD* pWd)
01183   {
01184     return FALSE != GetStringTypeExA(lc, dwT, pS, nSize, pWd);
01185   }
01186   inline bool wsGetStringType(LCID lc, DWORD dwT, PCWSTR pS, int nSize, 
01187     WORD* pWd)
01188   {
01189     return FALSE != GetStringTypeExW(lc, dwT, pS, nSize, pWd);
01190   }
01191 
01192 
01193   template<typename CT>
01194     inline bool ssisspace (CT t)
01195   { 
01196     WORD toYourMother;
01197     return  wsGetStringType(GetThreadLocale(), CT_CTYPE1, &t, 1, &toYourMother)
01198       && 0 != (C1_BLANK & toYourMother);
01199   }
01200 
01201 #endif
01202 
01203 // If they defined SS_NO_REFCOUNT, then we must convert all assignments
01204 
01205 #if defined (_MSC_VER) && (_MSC_VER < 1300)
01206   #ifdef SS_NO_REFCOUNT
01207     #define SSREF(x) (x).c_str()
01208   #else
01209     #define SSREF(x) (x)
01210   #endif
01211 #else
01212   #define SSREF(x) (x)
01213 #endif

01215 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
01216 // sslen: strlen/wcslen wrappers
01217 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
01218 template<typename CT> inline int sslen(const CT* pT)
01219 {
01220   return 0 == pT ? 0 : (int)std::basic_string<CT>::traits_type::length(pT);
01221 //  return 0 == pT ? 0 : std::char_traits<CT>::length(pT);
01222 }
01223 inline SS_NOTHROW int sslen(const std::string& s)
01224 {
01225   return static_cast<int>(s.length());
01226 }
01227 inline SS_NOTHROW int sslen(const std::wstring& s)
01228 {
01229   return static_cast<int>(s.length());
01230 }
01231 
01232 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
01233 // sstolower/sstoupper -- convert characters to upper/lower case
01234 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
01235 
01236 #ifdef SS_NO_LOCALE
01237   inline char sstoupper(char ch)    { return (char)::toupper(ch); }
01238   inline wchar_t sstoupper(wchar_t ch){ return (wchar_t)::towupper(ch); }
01239   inline char sstolower(char ch)    { return (char)::tolower(ch); }
01240   inline wchar_t sstolower(wchar_t ch){ return (wchar_t)::tolower(ch); }
01241 #else
01242   template<typename CT>
01243   inline CT sstolower(const CT& t, const std::locale& loc = std::locale())
01244   {
01245     return std::tolower<CT>(t, loc);
01246   }
01247   template<typename CT>
01248   inline CT sstoupper(const CT& t, const std::locale& loc = std::locale())
01249   {
01250     return std::toupper<CT>(t, loc);
01251   }
01252 #endif
01253 
01254 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
01255 // ssasn: assignment functions -- assign "sSrc" to "sDst"
01256 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
01257 typedef std::string::size_type    SS_SIZETYPE; // just for shorthand, really
01258 typedef std::string::pointer    SS_PTRTYPE;  
01259 typedef std::wstring::size_type   SW_SIZETYPE;
01260 typedef std::wstring::pointer   SW_PTRTYPE;  
01261 
01262 inline void ssasn(std::string& sDst, const std::string& sSrc)
01263 {
01264   if ( sDst.c_str() != sSrc.c_str() )
01265   {
01266     sDst.erase();
01267     sDst.assign(SSREF(sSrc));
01268   }
01269 }
01270 inline void ssasn(std::string& sDst, PCSTR pA)
01271 {
01272   // Watch out for NULLs, as always.
01273 
01274   if ( 0 == pA )
01275   {
01276     sDst.erase();
01277   }
01278 
01279   // If pA actually points to part of sDst, we must NOT erase(), but
01280   // rather take a substring
01281 
01282   else if ( pA >= sDst.c_str() && pA <= sDst.c_str() + sDst.size() )
01283   {
01284     sDst =sDst.substr(static_cast<SS_SIZETYPE>(pA-sDst.c_str()));
01285   }
01286 
01287   // Otherwise (most cases) apply the assignment bug fix, if applicable
01288   // and do the assignment
01289 
01290   else
01291   {
01292     Q172398(sDst);
01293     sDst.assign(pA);
01294   }
01295 }
01296 inline void ssasn(std::string& sDst, const std::wstring& sSrc)
01297 {
01298   if ( sSrc.empty() )
01299   {
01300     sDst.erase();
01301   }
01302   else
01303   {
01304     int nDst  = static_cast<int>(sSrc.size());
01305 
01306     // In MBCS builds, pad the buffer to account for the possibility of
01307     // some 3 byte characters.  Not perfect but should get most cases.
01308 
01309 #ifdef SS_MBCS
01310     nDst  = static_cast<int>(static_cast<double>(nDst) * 1.3);
01311 #endif
01312 
01313     sDst.resize(nDst+1);
01314     PCSTR szCvt = StdCodeCvt(const_cast<SS_PTRTYPE>(sDst.data()), nDst,
01315       sSrc.c_str(), static_cast<int>(sSrc.size()));
01316 
01317     // In MBCS builds, we don't know how long the destination string will be.
01318 
01319 #ifdef SS_MBCS
01320     sDst.resize(sslen(szCvt));
01321 #else
01322     szCvt;
01323     sDst.resize(sSrc.size());
01324 #endif
01325   }
01326 }
01327 inline void ssasn(std::string& sDst, PCWSTR pW)
01328 {
01329   int nSrc  = sslen(pW);
01330   if ( nSrc > 0 )
01331   {
01332     int nSrc  = sslen(pW);
01333     int nDst  = nSrc;
01334 
01335     // In MBCS builds, pad the buffer to account for the possibility of
01336     // some 3 byte characters.  Not perfect but should get most cases.
01337 
01338 #ifdef SS_MBCS
01339     nDst  = static_cast<int>(static_cast<double>(nDst) * 1.3);
01340 #endif
01341 
01342     sDst.resize(nDst + 1);
01343     PCSTR szCvt = StdCodeCvt(const_cast<SS_PTRTYPE>(sDst.data()), nDst,
01344       pW, nSrc);
01345 
01346     // In MBCS builds, we don't know how long the destination string will be.
01347 
01348 #ifdef SS_MBCS
01349     sDst.resize(sslen(szCvt));
01350 #else
01351     sDst.resize(nDst);
01352     szCvt;
01353 #endif
01354   }
01355   else
01356   {
01357     sDst.erase();
01358   }
01359 }
01360 inline void ssasn(std::string& sDst, const int nNull)
01361 {
01362   UNUSED(nNull);
01363   ASSERT(nNull==0);
01364   sDst.assign("");
01365 } 
01366 inline void ssasn(std::wstring& sDst, const std::wstring& sSrc)
01367 {
01368   if ( sDst.c_str() != sSrc.c_str() )
01369   {
01370     sDst.erase();
01371     sDst.assign(SSREF(sSrc));
01372   }
01373 }
01374 inline void ssasn(std::wstring& sDst, PCWSTR pW)
01375 {
01376   // Watch out for NULLs, as always.
01377 
01378   if ( 0 == pW )
01379   {
01380     sDst.erase();
01381   }
01382 
01383   // If pW actually points to part of sDst, we must NOT erase(), but
01384   // rather take a substring
01385 
01386   else if ( pW >= sDst.c_str() && pW <= sDst.c_str() + sDst.size() )
01387   {
01388     sDst = sDst.substr(static_cast<SW_SIZETYPE>(pW-sDst.c_str()));
01389   }
01390 
01391   // Otherwise (most cases) apply the assignment bug fix, if applicable
01392   // and do the assignment
01393 
01394   else
01395   {
01396     Q172398(sDst);
01397     sDst.assign(pW);
01398   }
01399 }
01400 #undef StrSizeType
01401 inline void ssasn(std::wstring& sDst, const std::string& sSrc)
01402 {
01403   if ( sSrc.empty() )
01404   {
01405     sDst.erase();
01406   }
01407   else
01408   {
01409     int nSrc  = static_cast<int>(sSrc.size());
01410     int nDst  = nSrc;
01411 
01412     sDst.resize(nSrc+1);
01413     PCWSTR szCvt = StdCodeCvt(const_cast<SW_PTRTYPE>(sDst.data()), nDst,
01414       sSrc.c_str(), nSrc);
01415 
01416     sDst.resize(sslen(szCvt));
01417   }
01418 }
01419 inline void ssasn(std::wstring& sDst, PCSTR pA)
01420 {
01421   int nSrc  = sslen(pA);
01422 
01423   if ( 0 == nSrc )
01424   {
01425     sDst.erase();
01426   }
01427   else
01428   {
01429     int nDst  = nSrc;
01430     sDst.resize(nDst+1);
01431     PCWSTR szCvt = StdCodeCvt(const_cast<SW_PTRTYPE>(sDst.data()), nDst, pA,
01432       nSrc);
01433 
01434     sDst.resize(sslen(szCvt));
01435   }
01436 }
01437 inline void ssasn(std::wstring& sDst, const int nNull)
01438 {
01439   UNUSED(nNull);
01440   ASSERT(nNull==0);
01441   sDst.assign(L"");
01442 }

01445 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
01446 // ssadd: string object concatenation -- add second argument to first
01447 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
01448 inline void ssadd(std::string& sDst, const std::wstring& sSrc)
01449 {
01450   int nSrc  = static_cast<int>(sSrc.size());
01451 
01452   if ( nSrc > 0 )
01453   {
01454     int nDst  = static_cast<int>(sDst.size());
01455     int nAdd  = nSrc;
01456 
01457     // In MBCS builds, pad the buffer to account for the possibility of
01458     // some 3 byte characters.  Not perfect but should get most cases.
01459 
01460 #ifdef SS_MBCS
01461     nAdd    = static_cast<int>(static_cast<double>(nAdd) * 1.3);
01462 #endif
01463 
01464     sDst.resize(nDst+nAdd+1);
01465     PCSTR szCvt = StdCodeCvt(const_cast<SS_PTRTYPE>(sDst.data()+nDst),
01466       nAdd, sSrc.c_str(), nSrc);
01467 
01468 #ifdef SS_MBCS
01469     sDst.resize(nDst + sslen(szCvt));
01470 #else
01471     sDst.resize(nDst + nAdd);
01472     szCvt;
01473 #endif
01474   }
01475 }
01476 inline void ssadd(std::string& sDst, const std::string& sSrc)
01477 {
01478   sDst += sSrc;
01479 }
01480 inline void ssadd(std::string& sDst, PCWSTR pW)
01481 {
01482   int nSrc    = sslen(pW);
01483   if ( nSrc > 0 )
01484   {
01485     int nDst  = static_cast<int>(sDst.size());
01486     int nAdd  = nSrc;
01487 
01488 #ifdef SS_MBCS
01489     nAdd  = static_cast<int>(static_cast<double>(nAdd) * 1.3);
01490 #endif
01491 
01492     sDst.resize(nDst + nAdd + 1);
01493     PCSTR szCvt = StdCodeCvt(const_cast<SS_PTRTYPE>(sDst.data()+nDst),
01494       nAdd, pW, nSrc);
01495 
01496 #ifdef SS_MBCS
01497     sDst.resize(nDst + sslen(szCvt));
01498 #else
01499     sDst.resize(nDst + nSrc);
01500     szCvt;
01501 #endif
01502   }
01503 }
01504 inline void ssadd(std::string& sDst, PCSTR pA)
01505 {
01506   if ( pA )
01507   {
01508     // If the string being added is our internal string or a part of our
01509     // internal string, then we must NOT do any reallocation without
01510     // first copying that string to another object (since we're using a
01511     // direct pointer)
01512 
01513     if ( pA >= sDst.c_str() && pA <= sDst.c_str()+sDst.length())
01514     {
01515       if ( sDst.capacity() <= sDst.size()+sslen(pA) )
01516         sDst.append(std::string(pA));
01517       else
01518         sDst.append(pA);
01519     }
01520     else
01521     {
01522       sDst.append(pA); 
01523     }
01524   }
01525 }
01526 inline void ssadd(std::wstring& sDst, const std::wstring& sSrc)
01527 {
01528   sDst += sSrc;
01529 }
01530 inline void ssadd(std::wstring& sDst, const std::string& sSrc)
01531 {
01532   if ( !sSrc.empty() )
01533   {
01534     int nSrc  = static_cast<int>(sSrc.size());
01535     int nDst  = static_cast<int>(sDst.size());
01536 
01537     sDst.resize(nDst + nSrc + 1);
01538     PCWSTR szCvt = StdCodeCvt(const_cast<SW_PTRTYPE>(sDst.data()+nDst), 
01539       nSrc, sSrc.c_str(), nSrc+1);
01540 
01541 #ifdef SS_MBCS
01542     sDst.resize(nDst + sslen(szCvt));
01543 #else
01544     sDst.resize(nDst + nSrc);
01545     szCvt;
01546 #endif
01547   }
01548 }
01549 inline void ssadd(std::wstring& sDst, PCSTR pA)
01550 {
01551   int nSrc    = sslen(pA);
01552 
01553   if ( nSrc > 0 )
01554   {
01555     int nDst  = static_cast<int>(sDst.size());
01556 
01557     sDst.resize(nDst + nSrc + 1);
01558     PCWSTR szCvt = StdCodeCvt(const_cast<SW_PTRTYPE>(sDst.data()+nDst),
01559       nSrc, pA, nSrc+1);
01560 
01561 #ifdef SS_MBCS
01562     sDst.resize(nDst + sslen(szCvt));
01563 #else
01564     sDst.resize(nDst + nSrc);
01565     szCvt;
01566 #endif
01567   }
01568 }
01569 inline void ssadd(std::wstring& sDst, PCWSTR pW)
01570 {
01571   if ( pW )
01572   {
01573     // If the string being added is our internal string or a part of our
01574     // internal string, then we must NOT do any reallocation without
01575     // first copying that string to another object (since we're using a
01576     // direct pointer)
01577 
01578     if ( pW >= sDst.c_str() && pW <= sDst.c_str()+sDst.length())
01579     {
01580       if ( sDst.capacity() <= sDst.size()+sslen(pW) )
01581         sDst.append(std::wstring(pW));
01582       else
01583         sDst.append(pW);
01584     }
01585     else
01586     {
01587       sDst.append(pW);
01588     }
01589   }
01590 }
01591 
01592 
01593 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
01594 // sscmp: comparison (case sensitive, not affected by locale)
01595 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
01596 template<typename CT>
01597 inline int sscmp(const CT* pA1, const CT* pA2)
01598 {
01599     CT f;
01600     CT l;
01601 
01602     do 
01603     {
01604       f = *(pA1++);
01605       l = *(pA2++);
01606     } while ( (f) && (f == l) );
01607 
01608     return (int)(f - l);
01609 }
01610 
01611 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
01612 // ssicmp: comparison (case INsensitive, not affected by locale)
01613 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
01614 template<typename CT>
01615 inline int ssicmp(const CT* pA1, const CT* pA2)
01616 {
01617   // Using the "C" locale = "not affected by locale"
01618 
01619   std::locale loc = std::locale::classic();
01620     const std::ctype<CT>& ct = SS_USE_FACET(loc, std::ctype<CT>);
01621     CT f;
01622     CT l;
01623 
01624     do 
01625     {
01626       f = ct.tolower(*(pA1++));
01627       l = ct.tolower(*(pA2++));
01628     } while ( (f) && (f == l) );
01629 
01630     return (int)(f - l);
01631 }
01632 
01633 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
01634 // ssupr/sslwr: Uppercase/Lowercase conversion functions
01635 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
01636 
01637 template<typename CT>
01638 inline void sslwr(CT* pT, size_t nLen, const std::locale& loc=std::locale())
01639 {
01640   SS_USE_FACET(loc, std::ctype<CT>).tolower(pT, pT+nLen);
01641 }
01642 template<typename CT>
01643 inline void ssupr(CT* pT, size_t nLen, const std::locale& loc=std::locale())
01644 {
01645   SS_USE_FACET(loc, std::ctype<CT>).toupper(pT, pT+nLen);
01646 }
01647 
01648 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
01649 // vsprintf/vswprintf or _vsnprintf/_vsnwprintf equivalents.  In standard
01650 // builds we can't use _vsnprintf/_vsnwsprintf because they're MS extensions.
01651 //
01652 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
01653 // Borland's headers put some ANSI "C" functions in the 'std' namespace. 
01654 // Promote them to the global namespace so we can use them here.
01655 
01656 #if defined(__BORLANDC__)
01657     using std::vsprintf;
01658     using std::vswprintf;
01659 #endif
01660 
01661   // GNU is supposed to have vsnprintf and vsnwprintf.  But only the newer
01662   // distributions do.
01663 
01664 #if defined(__GNUC__)
01665 
01666   inline int ssvsprintf(PSTR pA, size_t nCount, PCSTR pFmtA, va_list vl)
01667   { 
01668     return vsnprintf(pA, nCount, pFmtA, vl);
01669   }
01670   inline int ssvsprintf(PWSTR pW, size_t nCount, PCWSTR pFmtW, va_list vl)
01671   {
01672     return vswprintf(pW, nCount, pFmtW, vl);
01673   }
01674 
01675   // Microsofties can use
01676 #elif defined(_MSC_VER) && !defined(SS_ANSI)
01677 
01678   inline int  ssnprintf(PSTR pA, size_t nCount, PCSTR pFmtA, va_list vl)
01679   { 
01680     return _vsnprintf(pA, nCount, pFmtA, vl);
01681   }
01682   inline int  ssnprintf(PWSTR pW, size_t nCount, PCWSTR pFmtW, va_list vl)
01683   {
01684     return _vsnwprintf(pW, nCount, pFmtW, vl);
01685   }
01686 
01687 #elif defined (SS_DANGEROUS_FORMAT)  // ignore buffer size parameter if needed?
01688 
01689   inline int ssvsprintf(PSTR pA, size_t /*nCount*/, PCSTR pFmtA, va_list vl)
01690   {
01691     return vsprintf(pA, pFmtA, vl);
01692   }
01693 
01694   inline int ssvsprintf(PWSTR pW, size_t nCount, PCWSTR pFmtW, va_list vl)
01695   {
01696     // JMO: Some distributions of the "C" have a version of vswprintf that
01697         // takes 3 arguments (e.g. Microsoft, Borland, GNU).  Others have a 
01698         // version which takes 4 arguments (an extra "count" argument in the
01699         // second position.  The best stab I can take at this so far is that if
01700         // you are NOT running with MS, Borland, or GNU, then I'll assume you
01701         // have the version that takes 4 arguments.
01702         //
01703         // I'm sure that these checks don't catch every platform correctly so if
01704         // you get compiler errors on one of the lines immediately below, it's
01705         // probably because your implemntation takes a different number of
01706         // arguments.  You can comment out the offending line (and use the
01707         // alternate version) or you can figure out what compiler flag to check
01708         // and add that preprocessor check in.  Regardless, if you get an error
01709         // on these lines, I'd sure like to hear from you about it.
01710         //
01711         // Thanks to Ronny Schulz for the SGI-specific checks here.
01712 
01713 //  #if !defined(__MWERKS__) && !defined(__SUNPRO_CC_COMPAT) && !defined(__SUNPRO_CC)
01714     #if    !defined(_MSC_VER) \
01715         && !defined (__BORLANDC__) \
01716         && !defined(__GNUC__) \
01717         && !defined(__sgi)
01718 
01719         return vswprintf(pW, nCount, pFmtW, vl);
01720 
01721     // suddenly with the current SGI 7.3 compiler there is no such function as
01722     // vswprintf and the substitute needs explicit casts to compile
01723 
01724     #elif defined(__sgi)
01725 
01726         nCount;
01727         return vsprintf( (char *)pW, (char *)pFmtW, vl);
01728 
01729     #else
01730 
01731         nCount;
01732         return vswprintf(pW, pFmtW, vl);
01733 
01734     #endif
01735 
01736   }
01737 
01738 #else 
01739 
01740   // GOT COMPILER PROBLEMS HERE?
01741   // ---------------------------
01742   // Does your compiler choke on one or more of the following 2 functions?  It
01743   // probably means that you don't have have either vsnprintf or vsnwprintf in
01744   // your version of the CRT.  This is understandable since neither is an ANSI
01745   // "C" function.  However it still leaves you in a dilemma.  In order to make
01746   // this code build, you're going to have to to use some non-length-checked
01747   // formatting functions that every CRT has:  vsprintf and vswprintf.  
01748   //
01749   // This is very dangerous.  With the proper erroneous (or malicious) code, it
01750   // can lead to buffer overlows and crashing your PC.  Use at your own risk
01751   // In order to use them, just #define SS_DANGEROUS_FORMAT at the top of
01752   // this file.
01753   //
01754   // Even THEN you might not be all the way home due to some non-conforming
01755   // distributions.  More on this in the comments below.
01756 
01757   inline int  ssnprintf(PSTR pA, size_t nCount, PCSTR pFmtA, va_list vl)
01758   {
01759   #ifdef _MSC_VER
01760       return _vsnprintf(pA, nCount, pFmtA, vl);
01761   #else
01762       return vsnprintf(pA, nCount, pFmtA, vl);
01763   #endif
01764   }
01765   inline int  ssnprintf(PWSTR pW, size_t nCount, PCWSTR pFmtW, va_list vl)
01766   {
01767   #ifdef _MSC_VER
01768       return _vsnwprintf(pW, nCount, pFmtW, vl);
01769   #else
01770       return vsnwprintf(pW, nCount, pFmtW, vl);
01771   #endif
01772   }
01773 
01774 #endif
01775 
01776 
01777 
01778 
01779 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
01780 // ssload: Type safe, overloaded ::LoadString wrappers
01781 // There is no equivalent of these in non-Win32-specific builds.  However, I'm
01782 // thinking that with the message facet, there might eventually be one
01783 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
01784 #if defined (SS_WIN32) && !defined(SS_ANSI)
01785   inline int ssload(HMODULE hInst, UINT uId, PSTR pBuf, int nMax)
01786   {
01787     return ::LoadStringA(hInst, uId, pBuf, nMax);
01788   }
01789   inline int ssload(HMODULE hInst, UINT uId, PWSTR pBuf, int nMax)
01790   {
01791     return ::LoadStringW(hInst, uId, pBuf, nMax);
01792   }
01793 #endif

01795 
01796 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
01797 // sscoll/ssicoll: Collation wrappers
01798 //    Note -- with MSVC I have reversed the arguments order here because the
01799 //    functions appear to return the opposite of what they should
01800 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
01801 #ifndef SS_NO_LOCALE
01802 template <typename CT>
01803 inline int sscoll(const CT* sz1, int nLen1, const CT* sz2, int nLen2)
01804 {
01805   const std::collate<CT>& coll =
01806     SS_USE_FACET(std::locale(), std::collate<CT>);
01807 
01808   return coll.compare(sz2, sz2+nLen2, sz1, sz1+nLen1);
01809 }
01810 template <typename CT>
01811 inline int ssicoll(const CT* sz1, int nLen1, const CT* sz2, int nLen2)
01812 {
01813   const std::locale loc;
01814   const std::collate<CT>& coll = SS_USE_FACET(loc, std::collate<CT>);
01815 
01816   // Some implementations seem to have trouble using the collate<>
01817   // facet typedefs so we'll just default to basic_string and hope
01818   // that's what the collate facet uses (which it generally should)
01819 
01820 //  std::collate<CT>::string_type s1(sz1);
01821 //  std::collate<CT>::string_type s2(sz2);
01822   const std::basic_string<CT> sEmpty;
01823     std::basic_string<CT> s1(sz1 ? sz1 : sEmpty.c_str());
01824     std::basic_string<CT> s2(sz2 ? sz2 : sEmpty.c_str());
01825 
01826   sslwr(const_cast<CT*>(s1.c_str()), nLen1, loc);
01827   sslwr(const_cast<CT*>(s2.c_str()), nLen2, loc);
01828   return coll.compare(s2.c_str(), s2.c_str()+nLen2,
01829             s1.c_str(), s1.c_str()+nLen1);
01830 }
01831 #endif
01832

01836 // Again -- no equivalent of these on non-Win32 builds but their might one day
01837 // be one if the message facet gets implemented
01838 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
01839 #if defined (SS_WIN32) && !defined(SS_ANSI)
01840   inline DWORD ssfmtmsg(DWORD dwFlags, LPCVOID pSrc, DWORD dwMsgId,
01841               DWORD dwLangId, PSTR pBuf, DWORD nSize,
01842               va_list* vlArgs)
01843   { 
01844     return FormatMessageA(dwFlags, pSrc, dwMsgId, dwLangId,
01845                 pBuf, nSize,vlArgs);
01846   }
01847   inline DWORD ssfmtmsg(DWORD dwFlags, LPCVOID pSrc, DWORD dwMsgId,
01848               DWORD dwLangId, PWSTR pBuf, DWORD nSize,
01849               va_list* vlArgs)
01850   {
01851     return FormatMessageW(dwFlags, pSrc, dwMsgId, dwLangId,
01852                 pBuf, nSize,vlArgs);
01853   }
01854 #else
01855 #endif

01858 
01859 // FUNCTION: sscpy.  Copies up to 'nMax' characters from pSrc to pDst.
01860 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
01861 // FUNCTION:  sscpy
01862 //    inline int sscpy(PSTR pDst, PCSTR pSrc, int nMax=-1);
01863 //    inline int sscpy(PUSTR pDst,  PCSTR pSrc, int nMax=-1)
01864 //    inline int sscpy(PSTR pDst, PCWSTR pSrc, int nMax=-1);
01865 //    inline int sscpy(PWSTR pDst, PCWSTR pSrc, int nMax=-1);
01866 //    inline int sscpy(PWSTR pDst, PCSTR pSrc, int nMax=-1);
01867 //
01868 // DESCRIPTION:
01869 //    This function is very much (but not exactly) like strcpy.  These
01870 //    overloads simplify copying one C-style string into another by allowing
01871 //    the caller to specify two different types of strings if necessary.
01872 //
01873 //    The strings must NOT overlap
01874 //
01875 //    "Character" is expressed in terms of the destination string, not
01876 //    the source.  If no 'nMax' argument is supplied, then the number of
01877 //    characters copied will be sslen(pSrc).  A NULL terminator will
01878 //    also be added so pDst must actually be big enough to hold nMax+1
01879 //    characters.  The return value is the number of characters copied,
01880 //    not including the NULL terminator.
01881 //
01882 // PARAMETERS: 
01883 //    pSrc - the string to be copied FROM.  May be a char based string, an
01884 //         MBCS string (in Win32 builds) or a wide string (wchar_t).
01885 //    pSrc - the string to be copied TO.  Also may be either MBCS or wide
01886 //    nMax - the maximum number of characters to be copied into szDest.  Note
01887 //         that this is expressed in whatever a "character" means to pDst.
01888 //         If pDst is a wchar_t type string than this will be the maximum
01889 //         number of wchar_ts that my be copied.  The pDst string must be
01890 //         large enough to hold least nMaxChars+1 characters.
01891 //         If the caller supplies no argument for nMax this is a signal to
01892 //         the routine to copy all the characters in pSrc, regardless of
01893 //         how long it is.
01894 //
01895 // RETURN VALUE: none
01896 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
01897 template<typename CT1, typename CT2>
01898 inline int sscpycvt(CT1* pDst, const CT2* pSrc, int nMax)
01899 {
01900   // Note -- we assume pDst is big enough to hold pSrc.  If not, we're in
01901   // big trouble.  No bounds checking.  Caveat emptor.
01902   
01903   int nSrc = sslen(pSrc);
01904 
01905   const CT1* szCvt = StdCodeCvt(pDst, nMax, pSrc, nSrc);
01906 
01907   // If we're copying the same size characters, then all the "code convert"
01908   // just did was basically memcpy so the #of characters copied is the same
01909   // as the number requested.  I should probably specialize this function
01910   // template to achieve this purpose as it is silly to do a runtime check
01911   // of a fact known at compile time.  I'll get around to it.
01912 
01913   return sslen(szCvt);
01914 }
01915 
01916 inline int sscpycvt(PSTR pDst, PCSTR pSrc, int nMax)
01917 {
01918   int nCount = nMax;
01919   for (; nCount > 0 && *pSrc; ++pSrc, ++pDst, --nCount)
01920     std::basic_string<char>::traits_type::assign(*pDst, *pSrc);
01921 
01922   *pDst =  '\0';
01923   return nMax - nCount;
01924 }
01925 inline int sscpycvt(PWSTR pDst, PCWSTR pSrc, int nMax)
01926 {
01927   int nCount = nMax;
01928   for (; nCount > 0 && *pSrc; ++pSrc, ++pDst, --nCount)
01929     std::basic_string<wchar_t>::traits_type::assign(*pDst, *pSrc);
01930 
01931   *pDst = L'\0';
01932   return nMax - nCount;
01933 }
01934 inline int sscpycvt(PWSTR pDst, PCSTR pSrc, int nMax)
01935 {
01936   // Note -- we assume pDst is big enough to hold pSrc.  If not, we're in
01937   // big trouble.  No bounds checking.  Caveat emptor.
01938 
01939   const PWSTR szCvt = StdCodeCvt(pDst, nMax, pSrc, nMax);
01940   return sslen(szCvt);
01941 }
01942 
01943 template<typename CT1, typename CT2>
01944 inline int sscpy(CT1* pDst, const CT2* pSrc, int nMax, int nLen)
01945 {
01946   return sscpycvt(pDst, pSrc, SSMIN(nMax, nLen));
01947 }
01948 template<typename CT1, typename CT2>
01949 inline int sscpy(CT1* pDst, const CT2* pSrc, int nMax)
01950 {
01951   return sscpycvt(pDst, pSrc, SSMIN(nMax, sslen(pSrc)));
01952 }
01953 template<typename CT1, typename CT2>
01954 inline int sscpy(CT1* pDst, const CT2* pSrc)
01955 {
01956   return sscpycvt(pDst, pSrc, sslen(pSrc));
01957 }
01958 template<typename CT1, typename CT2>
01959 inline int sscpy(CT1* pDst, const std::basic_string<CT2>& sSrc, int nMax)
01960 {
01961   return sscpycvt(pDst, sSrc.c_str(), SSMIN(nMax, (int)sSrc.length()));
01962 }
01963 template<typename CT1, typename CT2>
01964 inline int sscpy(CT1* pDst, const std::basic_string<CT2>& sSrc)
01965 {
01966   return sscpycvt(pDst, sSrc.c_str(), (int)sSrc.length());
01967 }
01968 
01969 #ifdef SS_INC_COMDEF
01970   template<typename CT1>
01971   inline int sscpy(CT1* pDst, const _bstr_t& bs, int nMax)
01972   {
01973     return sscpycvt(pDst, static_cast<PCOLESTR>(bs),
01974             SSMIN(nMax, static_cast<int>(bs.length())));
01975   }
01976   template<typename CT1>
01977   inline int sscpy(CT1* pDst, const _bstr_t& bs)
01978   {
01979     return sscpy(pDst, bs, static_cast<int>(bs.length()));
01980   }
01981 #endif
01982 
01983 
01984 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
01985 // Functional objects for changing case.  They also let you pass locales
01986 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
01987 
01988 #ifdef SS_NO_LOCALE
01989   template<typename CT>
01990   struct SSToUpper : public std::unary_function<CT, CT>
01991   {
01992     inline CT operator()(const CT& t) const
01993     {
01994       return sstoupper(t);
01995     }
01996   };
01997   template<typename CT>
01998   struct SSToLower : public std::unary_function<CT, CT>
01999   {
02000     inline CT operator()(const CT& t) const
02001     {
02002       return sstolower(t);
02003     }
02004   };
02005 #else
02006   template<typename CT>
02007   struct SSToUpper : public std::binary_function<CT, std::locale, CT>
02008   {
02009     inline CT operator()(const CT& t, const std::locale& loc) const
02010     {
02011       return sstoupper<CT>(t, loc);
02012     }
02013   };
02014   template<typename CT>
02015   struct SSToLower : public std::binary_function<CT, std::locale, CT>
02016   {
02017     inline CT operator()(const CT& t, const std::locale& loc) const
02018     {
02019       return sstolower<CT>(t, loc);
02020     }
02021   };
02022 #endif
02023 
02024 // This struct is used for TrimRight() and TrimLeft() function implementations.
02025 //template<typename CT>
02026 //struct NotSpace : public std::unary_function<CT, bool>
02027 //{
02028 //  const std::locale& loc;
02029 //  inline NotSpace(const std::locale& locArg) : loc(locArg) {}
02030 //  inline bool operator() (CT t) { return !std::isspace(t, loc); }
02031 //};
02032 template<typename CT>
02033 struct NotSpace : public std::unary_function<CT, bool>
02034 {
02035   // DINKUMWARE BUG:
02036   // Note -- using std::isspace in a COM DLL gives us access violations
02037   // because it causes the dynamic addition of a function to be called
02038   // when the library shuts down.  Unfortunately the list is maintained
02039   // in DLL memory but the function is in static memory.  So the COM DLL
02040   // goes away along with the function that was supposed to be called,
02041   // and then later when the DLL CRT shuts down it unloads the list and
02042   // tries to call the long-gone function.
02043   // This is DinkumWare's implementation problem.  If you encounter this
02044   // problem, you may replace the calls here with good old isspace() and
02045   // iswspace() from the CRT unless they specify SS_ANSI
02046     
02047 #ifdef SS_NO_LOCALE
02048   
02049   bool operator() (CT t) const { return !ssisspace(t); }
02050 
02051 #else
02052   const std::locale loc;
02053   NotSpace(const std::locale& locArg=std::locale()) : loc(locArg) {}
02054   bool operator() (CT t) const { return !std::isspace(t, loc); }
02055 #endif
02056 };
02057 
02058 
02059 
02060 
02061 //      Now we can define the template (finally!)
02062 // =============================================================================
02063 // TEMPLATE: CStdStr
02064 //    template<typename CT> class CStdStr : public std::basic_string<CT>
02065 //
02066 // REMARKS:
02067 //    This template derives from basic_string<CT> and adds some MFC CString-
02068 //    like functionality
02069 //
02070 //    Basically, this is my attempt to make Standard C++ library strings as
02071 //    easy to use as the MFC CString class.
02072 //
02073 //    Note that although this is a template, it makes the assumption that the
02074 //    template argument (CT, the character type) is either char or wchar_t.  
02075 // =============================================================================
02076 
02077 //#define CStdStr _SS // avoid compiler warning 4786
02078 
02079 //    template<typename ARG> ARG& FmtArg(ARG& arg)  { return arg; }
02080 //    PCSTR  FmtArg(const std::string& arg)  { return arg.c_str(); }
02081 //    PCWSTR FmtArg(const std::wstring& arg) { return arg.c_str(); }
02082 
02083 template<typename ARG>
02084 struct FmtArg
02085 {
02086     explicit FmtArg(const ARG& arg) : a_(arg) {}
02087     const ARG& operator()() const { return a_; }
02088     const ARG& a_;
02089 private:
02090     FmtArg& operator=(const FmtArg&) { return *this; }
02091 };
02092 
02093 template<typename CT>
02094 class CStdStr : public std::basic_string<CT>
02095 {
02096   // Typedefs for shorter names.  Using these names also appears to help
02097   // us avoid some ambiguities that otherwise arise on some platforms
02098 
02099   #define MYBASE std::basic_string<CT>         // my base class
02100   //typedef typename std::basic_string<CT>    MYBASE;  // my base class
02101   typedef CStdStr<CT>             MYTYPE;  // myself
02102   typedef typename MYBASE::const_pointer    PCMYSTR; // PCSTR or PCWSTR 
02103   typedef typename MYBASE::pointer      PMYSTR;  // PSTR or PWSTR
02104   typedef typename MYBASE::iterator     MYITER;  // my iterator type
02105   typedef typename MYBASE::const_iterator   MYCITER; // you get the idea...
02106   typedef typename MYBASE::reverse_iterator MYRITER;
02107   typedef typename MYBASE::size_type      MYSIZE;   
02108   typedef typename MYBASE::value_type     MYVAL; 
02109   typedef typename MYBASE::allocator_type   MYALLOC;
02110   
02111 public:
02112   // shorthand conversion from PCTSTR to string resource ID
02113   #define SSRES(pctstr)  LOWORD(reinterpret_cast<unsigned long>(pctstr))  
02114 
02115   bool TryLoad(const void* pT)
02116   {
02117     bool bLoaded = false;
02118 
02119 #if defined(SS_WIN32) && !defined(SS_ANSI)
02120     if ( ( pT != NULL ) && SS_IS_INTRESOURCE(pT) )
02121     {
02122       UINT nId = LOWORD(reinterpret_cast<unsigned long>(pT));
02123       if ( !LoadString(nId) )
02124       {
02125         TRACE(_T("Can't load string %u\n"), SSRES(pT));
02126       }
02127       bLoaded = true;
02128     }
02129 #endif
02130 
02131     return bLoaded;
02132   }
02133 
02134 
02135   // CStdStr inline constructors
02136   CStdStr()
02137   {
02138   }
02139 
02140   CStdStr(const MYTYPE& str) : MYBASE(SSREF(str))
02141   {
02142   }
02143 
02144   CStdStr(const std::string& str)
02145   {
02146     ssasn(*this, SSREF(str));
02147   }
02148 
02149   CStdStr(const std::wstring& str)
02150   {
02151     ssasn(*this, SSREF(str));
02152   }
02153 
02154   CStdStr(PCMYSTR pT, MYSIZE n) : MYBASE(pT, n)
02155   {
02156   }
02157 
02158 #ifdef SS_UNSIGNED
02159   CStdStr(PCUSTR pU)
02160   {
02161     *this = reinterpret_cast<PCSTR>(pU);
02162   }
02163 #endif
02164 
02165   CStdStr(PCSTR pA)
02166   {
02167   #ifdef SS_ANSI
02168     *this = pA;
02169   #else
02170     if ( !TryLoad(pA) )
02171       *this = pA;
02172   #endif
02173   }
02174 
02175   CStdStr(PCWSTR pW)
02176   {
02177   #ifdef SS_ANSI
02178     *this = pW;
02179   #else
02180     if ( !TryLoad(pW) )
02181       *this = pW;
02182   #endif
02183   }
02184 
02185   CStdStr(MYCITER first, MYCITER last)
02186     : MYBASE(first, last)
02187   {
02188   }
02189 
02190   CStdStr(MYSIZE nSize, MYVAL ch, const MYALLOC& al=MYALLOC())
02191     : MYBASE(nSize, ch, al)
02192   {
02193   }
02194 
02195   #ifdef SS_INC_COMDEF
02196     CStdStr(const _bstr_t& bstr)
02197     {
02198       if ( bstr.length() > 0 )
02199         this->append(static_cast<PCMYSTR>(bstr), bstr.length());
02200     }
02201   #endif
02202 
02203   // CStdStr inline assignment operators -- the ssasn function now takes care
02204   // of fixing  the MSVC assignment bug (see knowledge base article Q172398).
02205   MYTYPE& operator=(const MYTYPE& str)
02206   { 
02207     ssasn(*this, str); 
02208     return *this;
02209   }
02210 
02211   MYTYPE& operator=(const std::string& str)
02212   {
02213     ssasn(*this, str);
02214     return *this;
02215   }
02216 
02217   MYTYPE& operator=(const std::wstring& str)
02218   {
02219     ssasn(*this, str);
02220     return *this;
02221   }
02222 
02223   MYTYPE& operator=(PCSTR pA)
02224   {
02225     ssasn(*this, pA);
02226     return *this;
02227   }
02228 
02229   MYTYPE& operator=(PCWSTR pW)
02230   {
02231     ssasn(*this, pW);
02232     return *this;
02233   }
02234 
02235 #ifdef SS_UNSIGNED
02236   MYTYPE& operator=(PCUSTR pU)
02237   {
02238     ssasn(*this, reinterpret_cast<PCSTR>(pU));
02239     return *this;
02240   }
02241 #endif
02242 
02243   MYTYPE& operator=(CT t)
02244   {
02245     Q172398(*this);
02246     this->assign(1, t);
02247     return *this;
02248   }
02249 
02250   #ifdef SS_INC_COMDEF
02251     MYTYPE& operator=(const _bstr_t& bstr)
02252     {
02253       if ( bstr.length() > 0 )
02254       {
02255         this->assign(static_cast<PCMYSTR>(bstr), bstr.length());
02256         return *this;
02257       }
02258       else
02259       {
02260         this->erase();
02261         return *this;
02262       }
02263     }
02264   #endif
02265 
02266 
02267   // Overloads  also needed to fix the MSVC assignment bug (KB: Q172398)
02268   //  *** Thanks to Pete The Plumber for catching this one ***
02269   // They also are compiled if you have explicitly turned off refcounting
02270   #if ( defined(_MSC_VER) && ( _MSC_VER < 1200 ) ) || defined(SS_NO_REFCOUNT) 
02271 
02272     MYTYPE& assign(const MYTYPE& str)
02273     {
02274       Q172398(*this);
02275       sscpy(GetBuffer(str.size()+1), SSREF(str));
02276       this->ReleaseBuffer(str.size());
02277       return *this;
02278     }
02279 
02280     MYTYPE& assign(const MYTYPE& str, MYSIZE nStart, MYSIZE nChars)
02281     {
02282       // This overload of basic_string::assign is supposed to assign up to
02283       // <nChars> or the NULL terminator, whichever comes first.  Since we
02284       // are about to call a less forgiving overload (in which <nChars>
02285       // must be a valid length), we must adjust the length here to a safe
02286       // value.  Thanks to Ullrich Pollähne for catching this bug
02287 
02288       nChars    = SSMIN(nChars, str.length() - nStart);
02289       MYTYPE strTemp(str.c_str()+nStart, nChars);
02290       Q172398(*this);
02291       this->assign(strTemp);
02292       return *this;
02293     }
02294 
02295     MYTYPE& assign(const MYBASE& str)
02296     {
02297       ssasn(*this, str);
02298       return *this;
02299     }
02300 
02301     MYTYPE& assign(const MYBASE& str, MYSIZE nStart, MYSIZE nChars)
02302     {
02303       // This overload of basic_string::assign is supposed to assign up to
02304       // <nChars> or the NULL terminator, whichever comes first.  Since we
02305       // are about to call a less forgiving overload (in which <nChars>
02306       // must be a valid length), we must adjust the length here to a safe
02307       // value. Thanks to Ullrich Pollähne for catching this bug
02308 
02309       nChars    = SSMIN(nChars, str.length() - nStart);
02310 
02311       // Watch out for assignment to self
02312 
02313       if ( this == &str )
02314       {
02315         MYTYPE strTemp(str.c_str() + nStart, nChars);
02316         static_cast<MYBASE*>(this)->assign(strTemp);
02317       }
02318       else
02319       {
02320         Q172398(*this);
02321         static_cast<MYBASE*>(this)->assign(str.c_str()+nStart, nChars);
02322       }
02323       return *this;
02324     }
02325 
02326     MYTYPE& assign(const CT* pC, MYSIZE nChars)
02327     {
02328       // Q172398 only fix -- erase before assigning, but not if we're
02329       // assigning from our own buffer
02330 
02331   #if defined ( _MSC_VER ) && ( _MSC_VER < 1200 )
02332       if ( !this->empty() &&
02333         ( pC < this->data() || pC > this->data() + this->capacity() ) )
02334       {
02335         this->erase();
02336       }
02337   #endif
02338       Q172398(*this);
02339       static_cast<MYBASE*>(this)->assign(pC, nChars);
02340       return *this;
02341     }
02342 
02343     MYTYPE& assign(MYSIZE nChars, MYVAL val)
02344     {
02345       Q172398(*this);
02346       static_cast<MYBASE*>(this)->assign(nChars, val);
02347       return *this;
02348     }
02349 
02350     MYTYPE& assign(const CT* pT)
02351     {
02352       return this->assign(pT, MYBASE::traits_type::length(pT));
02353     }
02354 
02355     MYTYPE& assign(MYCITER iterFirst, MYCITER iterLast)
02356     {
02357   #if defined ( _MSC_VER ) && ( _MSC_VER < 1200 ) 
02358       // Q172398 fix.  don't call erase() if we're assigning from ourself
02359       if ( iterFirst < this->begin() ||
02360                  iterFirst > this->begin() + this->size() )
02361             {
02362         this->erase()
02363             }
02364   #endif
02365       this->replace(this->begin(), this->end(), iterFirst, iterLast);
02366       return *this;
02367     }
02368   #endif
02369 
02370 
02371   // -------------------------------------------------------------------------
02372   // CStdStr inline concatenation.
02373   // -------------------------------------------------------------------------
02374   MYTYPE& operator+=(const MYTYPE& str)
02375   {
02376     ssadd(*this, str);
02377     return *this;
02378   }
02379

02381   {
02382     ssadd(*this, str);
02383     return *this; 
02384   }

02387   {
02388     ssadd(*this, str);
02389     return *this;
02390   }

02395     return *this;
02396   }

02399   {
02400     ssadd(*this, pW);
02401     return *this;
02402   }

02404   MYTYPE& operator+=(CT t)
02405   {
02406     this->append(1, t);
02407     return *this;
02408   }
02409   #ifdef SS_INC_COMDEF  // if we have _bstr_t, define a += for it too.
02410     MYTYPE& operator+=(const _bstr_t& bstr)
02411     {
02412       return this->operator+=(static_cast<PCMYSTR>(bstr));
02413     }
